Answer: Elon.1- SpaceX:Elon and the SpaceX Team have proven them wrong.Elon has a mission to make Mars habitable in case the earth is no longer a viable option.I wouldn’t be surprised if SpaceX successfully sends men to Mars in this decade.2- TeslaTesla has solved problems like slow charging, short range, slow speed, and slow acceleration, plus has made EVs affordable.Now allElon.1- SpaceX:Elon and the SpaceX Team have proven them wrong.Elon has a mission to make Mars habitable in case the earth is no longer a viable option.I wouldn’t be surprised if SpaceX successfully sends men to Mars in this decade.2- TeslaTesla has solved problems like slow charging, short range, slow speed, and slow acceleration, plus has made EVs affordable.Now all the car industry is trying to catch up with Elon and the Tesla Team. Personally, I don’t think they have the corporate culture and innovative thinking to do so.Tesla will continue to revolutionize the car industry.3- Tesla BatteriesFounded in 2006, Elon is seeking to make renewable energy something that every home can afford plus revolutionize the battery efficiency of the Tesla cars.SolarCity (another of Elon’s ventures) designs and installs clean energy systems in residential and commercial settings.Elon’s goal is that by using SolarCity’s solar energy and Tesla batteries, households can become less dependent on the electric grid, power their Tesla vehicle, and reduce their footprint on the environment.With global warming in the front of the minds of governments and people worldwide, I expect that Elon will continue to revolutionize this industry.4- The HyperloopPassengers will be able to enter a 2-meter wide pod to be zipped through a long tube. The entire thing is expected to run on renewable electric energy.The Hyperloop is being tested and has proven to be successful. We will see Elon’s creation again revolutionize transportation by the end of this decade.Elon with the Boring Company is also working on neuroscience, education, AI, self-driving cars, traffic problems.Elon is changing the world in many ways — I expect to see Elon reap much of what he has sown, during this decade.Extraordinary genius!Go Elon!

Answer: I think that we have several of those species here on earth.Their technological acheivements look very different from ours, to such an extent that we (in our all-pervading humility) are completely unable to notice them.You free to say that medicine, linguistics, logics, calculus, etc. are not scientific acheivements. There must also be technologies that are completely unknown to us.I´ve seen dolphins manipulate objects by ultrasound… move bubbles in diractions that contradict gravity, for example. We know that they use very sofisticated and advanced medicine.We know that their communications bI think that we have several of those species here on earth.Their technological acheivements look very different from ours, to such an extent that we (in our all-pervading humility) are completely unable to notice them.You free to say that medicine, linguistics, logics, calculus, etc. are not scientific acheivements. There must also be technologies that are completely unknown to us.I´ve seen dolphins manipulate objects by ultrasound… move bubbles in diractions that contradict gravity, for example. We know that they use very sofisticated and advanced medicine.We know that their communications bandwith is better than some computer networks we have. We must assume that their data compressing and error finding algorhytms are better than ours (after so many millions of years of development). We should assume that they are able to transmit pictures, audio files and maybe even video clips.Conclusion:Our “not noticing” is so overstated.We cannot judge what we don´t know (…and we know so little)

Answer: How technological?Nothing about living underwater would stop such a species from building shelters, nets, stone or other natural material tools. Nor would it stop them from farming and animal husbandry.Would it stop them from discovering fire, electricity, metallurgy, explosives, etc?We can’t say that there aren’t other technological pathways that could lead to the discovery of equivalent capabilities without mastering fire.But, even assuming fire is necessary for all that…If the planet has an air/water or water/land interface, and an oxygenated atmosphere, and our aquatic species ends up domeHow technological?Nothing about living underwater would stop such a species from building shelters, nets, stone or other natural material tools. Nor would it stop them from farming and animal husbandry.Would it stop them from discovering fire, electricity, metallurgy, explosives, etc?We can’t say that there aren’t other technological pathways that could lead to the discovery of equivalent capabilities without mastering fire.But, even assuming fire is necessary for all that…If the planet has an air/water or water/land interface, and an oxygenated atmosphere, and our aquatic species ends up domesticating an animal that is amphibious, or a food crop that, say, floats near the ocean surface (like kelp on Earth), then that act of domestication gives them the opportunity to access the air. In caring for their floating crop, they will inevitably learn to make floating platforms. By managing their amphibious livestock, they gain a beast of burden that can pull cargo out of the sea and on to the seashore.And with access to air, the discovery of fire is just a matter of time. It might come later in their history than for humans on Earth, but it will come.Even with no access to surface air, if they manage to develop a science of chemistry, they might still discover fire eventually. Fire is just a redox reaction, after all.Perhaps it might be harder, and perhaps it might take longer, but it certainly does not appear impossible.

Answer: The phrase ‘in demand’ means very different things when you consider them from the positions of consumer, industry pioneer and someone looking to invest their time in learning a skill.When consider the overall viability of a technology, the Gartner Hype Cycle is a very useful and intuitive tool to look at in order to decide where a technology is in its lifetime.The following is the Gartner Hype Cycle for most technologies for the year 2018.In a nutshell; every technology goes through the specified 5 stages in its lifetime.They follow a set pattern from the perspective of social expectation; whThe phrase ‘in demand’ means very different things when you consider them from the positions of consumer, industry pioneer and someone looking to invest their time in learning a skill.When consider the overall viability of a technology, the Gartner Hype Cycle is a very useful and intuitive tool to look at in order to decide where a technology is in its lifetime.The following is the Gartner Hype Cycle for most technologies for the year 2018.In a nutshell; every technology goes through the specified 5 stages in its lifetime.They follow a set pattern from the perspective of social expectation; which would translate here to the ‘demand’.Some technologies go through the cycle much quicker than others; and some technologies might linger at a particular stage.Now, let’s look at each of the individual demands.Finally; the tech world is just like Hollywood. A select few make it, and it’s only because we like them so badly. The difference is, though, that technologies often intertwine, branching off into niche and very ad hoc topics. But you would not want to write them off just yet, because you never know what the world suddenly may think it needs!

Answer: Definitely C++ and Python.C++ to do the work in the framework and Python to command the framework.Yes, Python is not the main language, the main language is C++. Python is the language that sends the requirements to the framework and presents the answers to humans. The real work is done in libraries written in C++.If your work can be done using algorithms that are already written in C++, you will probably only use Python to handle the framework to do well know tasks. However, if you are developing new algorithms, you must implement them in CDefinitely C++ and Python.C++ to do the work in the framework and Python to command the framework.Yes, Python is not the main language, the main language is C++. Python is the language that sends the requirements to the framework and presents the answers to humans. The real work is done in libraries written in C++.If your work can be done using algorithms that are already written in C++, you will probably only use Python to handle the framework to do well know tasks. However, if you are developing new algorithms, you must implement them in C++.The more you stray from the existing algorithms, the more you need to work in C++. The more you use existing algorithms, the more you will use Python.Therefore, C++ and Python make up a very powerful tool that allows you to be very efficient, thinking at different levels of abstraction.I believe that this powerful tool (C++ - Python) is not unique to AI and could be used in almost all scientific investigations.Finally, I must clarify that of that pair, C++ today is insubtituible, while Python can be replaced by other languages ​​such as Julia or R. However, today, Python is the dominant language.I recommend you to read:Regards.If this answer was helpful,

Answer: These are two very very very very very very very different fields. Ultimately it depends on what you want to do and what floats your boat.If you’re the sort of logical person who loves analysing things and doing loads of maths, I’d go with data science.If you’re more creative and want to enjoy generally less stressful existence (which is totally fine), web development is more for you.And of course, I’m by no means saying that you can’t learn both - modelling things with data science by day; fighting crime and developing web apps by night - but atm there are more web development jobs availableThese are two very very very very very very very different fields. Ultimately it depends on what you want to do and what floats your boat.If you’re the sort of logical person who loves analysing things and doing loads of maths, I’d go with data science.If you’re more creative and want to enjoy generally less stressful existence (which is totally fine), web development is more for you.And of course, I’m by no means saying that you can’t learn both - modelling things with data science by day; fighting crime and developing web apps by night - but atm there are more web development jobs available and web development is generally more chill. Also, it’s easier to be a freelance web developer than a freelance data scientist ;) .Love fromYour best friend peter

Answer: Take a look atFront End:Take a look atFront End:The range of devices can escalate quickly depending on what your application plans to support (5 or more OS (win, mac, Linux, android, ios, IoT devices) X 5 or more browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari, IE…) X 4 or more resolutions (range from 320*568 to 2560*937 ultra-wide screens)) which put the total environments above 100 to account in your code/styles/markup, complex enough?Back End:Dev Ops:At this point you see web development is huge, that’s why specializations exist, me myself am a front end dev specializing in Angular, React, React Native & Ionic, if I were to list what I know from the front-end graph, I would own 60% of the recommended ones (yellow), and yet I’m working with the biggest IT companies here in Colombia.Web development is complex, it’s also rewarding if you like to solve complex problems and challenge yourself, you combine that with the high demand and high remuneration (due to both the demand and the difficulty/responsibility) and you can guess it is very well worth it, as long as you have the skills, companies will hire, so go for it.

Answer: I think the biggest change to recording technology (or at the least the one the Beatles made most use of) was multitrack recording. It was no longer necessary to play the song as a band and get a perfect take. That said, they usually started with a basic instrumental "best" take from which to build. Then they added all of the various effects they wanted, and took as much time as needed to perfect individual overdubs.Almost everything the Beatles recorded was on 4-track. They used 8-track on some of the White Album and Abbey Road. It wasn't much, but it was a significant advantage over what waI think the biggest change to recording technology (or at the least the one the Beatles made most use of) was multitrack recording. It was no longer necessary to play the song as a band and get a perfect take. That said, they usually started with a basic instrumental "best" take from which to build. Then they added all of the various effects they wanted, and took as much time as needed to perfect individual overdubs.Almost everything the Beatles recorded was on 4-track. They used 8-track on some of the White Album and Abbey Road. It wasn't much, but it was a significant advantage over what was available in the fifties.It's hard to overestimate the role of the songwriting. Many if the songs could have been captured on 2 track and been quite fulfilling.
